name: Web Development Basics
description: Core concepts in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript for modern web development

cards.question: What is the purpose of semantic HTML?
options: To give meaning to web content for better accessibility and SEO
To add animations to web pages
cards.description: Semantic HTML uses tags that clearly describe their meaning and content, rather than just how they appear. This improves accessibility for screen readers, helps search engines understand content, and makes code more maintainable.

cards.question: What is the CSS Box Model?
cards.hint: Every element is a box with multiple layers
options: The layout system describing content, padding, border, and margin
cards.description: The CSS Box Model describes how every HTML element is rendered as a rectangular box with four areas: content, padding (space inside border), border, and margin (space outside border). Understanding this is crucial for layout control.

cards.question: What is event bubbling in JavaScript?
options: When an event propagates from child to parent elements
cards.description: Event bubbling is the process where an event triggered on a nested element propagates up through its ancestors in the DOM tree. This allows parent elements to respond to events on their children. Use event.stopPropagation() to prevent bubbling.

cards.question: What is the difference between let, const, and var?
options: let and const are block-scoped; var is function-scoped; const can't be reassigned
var is modern, let and const are deprecated
cards.description: var is function-scoped and hoisted, which can lead to bugs. let is block-scoped and can be reassigned. const is also block-scoped but cannot be reassigned (though object properties can still be modified). Modern code should prefer let and const.

cards.question: What is a Promise in JavaScript?
options: A commitment to write clean code
An object representing eventual completion or failure of an async operation
A function that always returns true
cards.description: A Promise is an object representing the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation. It has three states: pending, fulfilled, or rejected. Promises provide a cleaner alternative to callback-based async code and can be chained.
